mods:titleInfo.mods:title: [Maria de las Angustias Josefa Antonia Bernabe or Doña Angustias de la Guerra (1815-1890), daughter of José de la Guerra y Noriega]

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 photographic print : albumen ; mount 17 x 11 cm

mods:mods.mods:note: In ms. on verso: She wears same mantilla as woman and girl in Tuttle & Lee, and Hayward & Muzzall photos. Daughter of José Antonio de la Guerra y Noriega; 1st marriage (in 1833) to Manuel Jimeño Casarin who died in 1854; 2nd marriage to Dr. James L. Ord, U.S. Army, in 1856. Boys are probably sons of Jimeño, her first husband (or grandsons?)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: [Plaza of the de la Guerra house, Santa Barbara]

mods:physicalDescription.mods:extent: 1 photographic print : stereograph, albumen ; mount 10 x 18 cm

mods:mods.mods:note: In ms. on verso: "Plaza" de la Guerra house, (site of El Paseo)... At far end are Doña Josefa, widow of Don Pablo de la Guerra, and her children, Carlos, Delfina, and Herminia. The shorter standing woman left is Francisca Dibblee, the other is the daughter of Don Francisco de la Guerra, brother of Don Pablo; he stands opposite her. The seated man at right is Captain Antonio de la Guerra, also brother of to Don Pablo - here sick and blind from Civil War service

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: [Maria de las Angustias Josefa Antonia Bernabe or Doña Angustias de la Guerra (1815-1890), daughter of José de la Guerra y Noriega]
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: 1 photographic print : albumen ; mount 17 x 11 cm
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In ms. on verso: She wears same mantilla as woman and girl in Tuttle & Lee, and Hayward & Muzzall photos. Daughter of José Antonio de la Guerra y Noriega; 1st marriage (in 1833) to Manuel Jimeño Casarin who died in 1854; 2nd marriage to Dr. James L. Ord, U.S. Army, in 1856. Boys are probably sons of Jimeño, her first husband (or grandsons?)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: [Plaza of the de la Guerra house, Santa Barbara]
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: 1 photographic print : stereograph, albumen ; mount 10 x 18 cm
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In ms. on verso: "Plaza" de la Guerra house, (site of El Paseo)... At far end are Doña Josefa, widow of Don Pablo de la Guerra, and her children, Carlos, Delfina, and Herminia. The shorter standing woman left is Francisca Dibblee, the other is the daughter of Don Francisco de la Guerra, brother of Don Pablo; he stands opposite her. The seated man at right is Captain Antonio de la Guerra, also brother of to Don Pablo - here sick and blind from Civil War service

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In ms. on verso: Like him who trusts to summer skies, And puts his little bark to sea, Is he who, lured by smiling eyes, Consigns his simple heart to thee; For fickle is the summer wind, And sadly may the bark be tossed; For those are sure to change thy mind, And then the wretched heart is lost. 10/1/81

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: [Parlor of the de la Guerra house, Santa Barbara]
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: 1 photographic print : stereograph, albumen ; mount 10 x 18 cm
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In ms. on verso: Parlor or sala (36 x 38 feet) de la Guerra house (site of El Paseo)... Figure next to door is Doña Josefa, widow of Pablo; other woman is daughter of Don Francisco de la Guerra, who is at the left. Portrait at left is of his father, Captain Don José Antonio de la Guerra. Portraits at end of room are of Thomas B. Dibblee and his wife, Francisca de la Guerra Dibblee. Oil portraits by Faquani [?] of New York in 1872
